7th July 2013

The Vanguard of Feeling

Featuring:

DUST & Dylan C

DUST are a Bushwick combo of superstar-like personalities who make dance music glimmering like the treasure at the end of every drop, their decimation is of all inhibition, they push the community of dancers towards a pulsar moment when shape-shifting becomes reality.

They do this by deploying classical dance elements and ingredients – the call of titanic sirens foreshadowing a raving dawn, the fuzzy wail of a pride of Roland lions, the elastic bounce of Chicago Transformers & the epic melodic flourishes of the disgraced italo nobility – without scholarly consideration for taste or style, but with the fierce élan of barbarians reclaiming the ruins of a dead civilisation.

This violent repossession is a recurring theme of dance history – as the b-boys did with the robots, and the Balearics did with, well, everything. Through it, the eternal truth of old myths is reaffirmed; as is the edge of ancient weapons, and this is right and proper.

A new dark age is upon us, and we welcome it enthralled.

Dust – Onset of Decimation

You can pre-order the S/T 12’’ from the awesome Mannequin Records.

Dylan C’s sprawling Samsara: Causes & Conditions contains another type of dance re-appropriation, transversal rather than sequential, and refining rather than roughening. The physical functions of dance remain perfectly fulfilled, and elevated by a touch of the sublime.

The 2-step shuffle that came to symbolise mindless materialism, tight dresses & Möet spillage is here purified by introspection, so that it can once again capture the lonely heartbeat of a city of glass.  The immaculate dynamics of modern house aren’t used to stretch Saturday Night into eternity, but instead act as conduits for beautiful dance routines whose memories will haunt us forever. We make peace with the sun, and raise our hands towards its warming glow.

Dylan C- Genuine Vibes

You can purchase Samsara from Holodeck Records.

5th July 2013

Astral Prayer

Featuring:

Geinoh Yamashirogumi

(art is The Navigators by Oscar Vargas)

A little while ago we had a go at unravelling the DNA of the music of AKIRA, the greatest animated film of all time. The army of non-musicians who breathed AKIRA’s soundtrack into life go by the name of Geinoh Yamashirogumi, and no two of their albums are the same.

Committed ethnomusicologists, Geinoh seem to study musical forms by posessing them. The pre-AKIRA Selections from Folk Music from Silkroad threads a musical cartography through Taiwan, India, Corsica, Georgia, Pakistan, Syria, and Turkey. Geinoh use nothing but their voices to make something astral and forever-sounding. This choral music sounds like the stars and should be sung by all who travel under them, as a prayer to ward off misadventure.

Geinoh Yamashirogumi – Ito Wo Tsumuideita Toki

Selections from Folk Music from Silkroad is currently out of print.

2nd July 2013

Small Orchestra

Featuring:

Andrew Clare

(Photography is by Kotori Kawashima)

Andrew Clare is better known as the frontman of Brighton noise rock perennials I’m Being Good, or as the genius illustrator and designer who, perhaps more than any of its writers, gave Plan B magazine a strikingly individual identity.

Though – judging by his website – he seems to consider his solo music something of a side project to his main creative outlets, this beautiful, minimal noise is up there with the very best of his work. Brainchild of Childbrain in particular is an intriguing sound puddle that has Andrew improvising a small orchestra of instruments around each other.

He uses space in the music like he does white on the page – as an undervalued resource, as a colour, instead of the absence of colour.

Andrew Clare – excerpt from Brainchild of Childbrain

Buy the full Brainchild of Childbrain at Bandcamp
